Concerned members of the
Hopkins community met with
the Hopkins Committee for Basic
Freedoms Tuesday, November 30
in Levering Hall. All those who
attended the public meeting were
incorporated into the committee.
The group discussed its relation with the administration.
it was suggested that the committee should develop detailed
proposals and present them to
the administration. Another suggestion was that the committee
should point out the inadequacies
of present administration policy
and use publicity to prod the
administration into action.
After some debate, it was generally decided that the administration has the experience and
the responsibility to work out
the necessary programs. The
committee's object will be to
work out feasible general programs, present details where
possible, and to publicize those
areas where the administration
does not act.
Subconunittees Formed
Eventually, the group decided
to split into three subcommittees on admissions, housing, and
employment. Each committee
Will investigate specific actions
bi its area and report back to
the group or the administration.
Until the next meeting, sched(tied for December 7 at 7:30
P.M., each committee could act
on its own if an opportunity
arose to aid desegregation of
the campus.
Approximately 25 people attended the meeting at various
times, although only 15 people
Were left to organize the corntnittees at the end. The majority
of the group consisted of gradUAW students, but several undergraduates and a member of the
faculty were also active.
Eugene Sobel, who informally
ehaired the meeting, listed some
of the action taken by the administration since the last meeting. The Physics Department
had hired a Negro for a technical
job and Robert Bilgrave, Director of Admissions, had gone to
Inv° Negro high schools in the
pity and had talked to the guidgrice personnel there. Mr. Bilgrave had earlier commented to
Committee members that he
would actively recruit from Negro
high schools if he could obtain
list of quality Negro schools.
Be also stated that underpriviged students might be accepted
students could be found to
tutor them in the skills that they
are lacking. The committees are
investigating these proposals.
Other Alternatives
programs
discussed
Other

were the obtaining of scholarship money for Negroes from
foundations; the Vromotion of
Hopkins in Negro areas by
alumni and students; and the
administration publicly supporting the open housing bill soon
to be considered by the city
council. The committee hopes to
work with the administration in
these and other areas.
The Committee for Basic Freedoms made its initial effort to
involve other members of the
Hopkins community at an open
meeting November 23. Although
no official representative of the
administration was present,Dean
Robert L. Strider attended "representing myself," and answered
questions during the discussion
period.
University Lethargy'
Reginald Lewis, of the faculty
of Morgan State College in Baltimore, attacked the current administration position as one of
"sterile
disengagement" and
"pensive inertia." He stated that
such a position is not consistent
with the role of the modern uni(Continued on Page 2)

As of last Monday evening the
Student Council was still =decided as to who will be invited
to the reception to be held before William Buckley's lecture
next Tuesday.
Jeff Griffith, referring to the
IFC-sponsored All-School Holocaust, promised it would never
happen again. The Council will
conduct a foreign policy poll in
hopes of obtaining an accurate
indication of student opinion on
the war in Vietnam.
Buckley, recent New York City
mayoral candidate, will deliver
the annual Student Council Lecture in Shriver Hall, Tuesday,
December 7th, at 4:00 p.m. His
topic will be "The Unmaking of
a Mayor," the subject of a book
he will soon write. Before the
lecture there will be a reception
to which about sixty people will
receive invitations. It was suggested that half a dozen prominent Goucher or Notre Dame
girls be invited. Bud Bozarth objected, saying that Hopkins students should have priority. No
firm decision was reached, but

Mr. Buckley, who polled nearly
a third of a million votes in the
mayoralty contest, first provoked
public attention by his best-selling book, God and Man at Yale.
It was the most widely reviewed
book of the year.
He later co-authored (with Brent
McCarthy and
Bozell)
His
Enemies, an examination of loyalty and security practices in
Washington.
Born in New York in 1925, Mr.
Buckley studied in England and
France. After serving in the army
during World War II, he entered
Yale University, graduating with

00000000000000000000000

ham, Willmoore Kendall, William
Rickenbacker, Mar Eastman and
John Dos Passos. He has been
invited to lectures on campuses
In every state of the Union and,
in the East, has spoken at Yale,
Harvard, Princeton, Columbia,
Cornell, Dartmouth, and The
University of Virginia.
Shelly Earp, President of the
Student Council, will introduce
Buckley to the Hopkins community. In announcing the lecture, Earp said that: "Mr.
Buckley's appearance at Hopkins
Is part of a continuing series of
addresses by prominent Americans. This kind of dialogue is a
vital part of the undergraduate
program at Hopkins."
Buckley will be met at Friendship airport by Shelly Earp and
a contingent of eminents from
the student council. Buckley will
be brought to campus and honored by a student council reception — the time and place of
the reception has not been released, however.

Campus Queen Crowned
Marian Cox, a freslunan from
Goucher College and the candidate from Adams House, was
crowned Fall Campus Queen at
ceremonies preceding the Nov.20
football game with Western
Maryland.
Miss Cox was selected from
eleven finalists, who were chosen
from twenty girls entered by the
fraternities and the dormitory
houses. The finalists were: Pat
Francisco of Mount St. Agnes,
nominated by Clark House;
Susan Palkovic from Hampton House, Willard's nominee;
ATO's Diane Vielmetti, from
Goucher; Nancy Thomas, Union
Memorial School of Nursing, DU;
Stephanie Meager, University of
Pennsylvania, Phi Ep; Sandy
Brazychi from Notre Dame, Phi
Gam; Virginia Moller, Mt. St.
Agnes, representing Phi Psi;
Tucker Burns, Notre Dame, Phi
Sig; and Jaque Rayner, Western
Maryland, by Sig Ep.
The new queen was given one
dozen long-stemmed American
beauty roses, an engraved charm,
dinner for two at the Chesapeake Restaurant, and a ticket
to the Pigskin Hop. Runners-up
were presented with wishbone
pins.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, DECEMBER 3, 1965

State's Attorney To Speak
Charles E. Moylan, Jr., State's
Attorney of Baltimore City, will
speak at a joint meeting
of the Hopkins Young Democrats
and Debate Council on Wednesday, December 8, at 4:00 P.M.
in the Reading Room of Levering Hall. The subject of Moylan's
talk will be "Crime in Baltimore."
This year's debate topic is
"Resolved: That law enforcement agencies in the United
States should be given greater
freedom in the investigation and
prosecution of crime." The topic
is chiefly concerned with recent
Supreme Court decisions which
place limitations on police and
states' attornies in their attempts to catch and convict
criminals. Moyan will discuss his
views on the Su,perne Court decisions during his speech.

The Young Democrats are cohosting the affair because Mr.
Moylan is widely regarded as a
political comer in the State of
Maryland. The State's Attorney
has already been asked to run
for Attorney-General of the
State on one ticket and smart
politicians are predicting that
he will be the next AttorneyGeneral and then Governor.
The debaters and the Young
Democrats expect a full house
for Mr. Moylan's visit. He will
be speaking the day after William F. Buckley's appearance
and "the more liberal members
of the Hopkins community regard Moylan's speech as a breath
of fresh air following the erstwhile New York mayoralty candidate," according to Jon Alpert,
who is president of both organizations.

Class Day Over
Class day went off well,
Booster Club President Griffith
reported, but no one seems to
know who won. Student participation was limited when a few
faculty members scheduled labs
for that Friday afternoon, a
practice which an administration
spokesman decried inasmuch as
the afternoon of the Friday before Thanksgiving is an official
University holiday.
The first and last Hopkins AllSchool blast was held two weeks
ago in what now remains of the
likYrC building. Several windows
were broken and doors were
ripped off their hinges. The
Major problem, however, was the
chaotic mess which the maintenance crew faced the following
day. Griffith admitted that "he
didn't realize that students—
especially freshmen—would go
ape as they did." He also noted
that many males attending the
affair were non-Hopkins men.

Returning to speak at Hopkins
will be a homecoming for Moylan who received his B.A. here
in 1952. Among other activities,
while he was at Hopkins he
served as president of the Council. Moylan went on to the University of Maryland Law School
where he was President of the
Student Bar Association and National Vice-President of the
American Law Students Association. Shortly thereafter he
entered the army and graduated
first in his class at the Army
Intelligence Center at Fort Holebird. After serving as a Counter
Intelligence agent in West Germany, Moylan returned to Baltimore and entered Maryland
politics. He has been State's Attorney for Baltimore City for
over a year and has also served
as President of the Maryland
Young Democratic Clubs, He is
now serving on the Board of
Directors of many public service
organizations including the National Conference of Christians
and Jews.

GRADUATE FORUM

A warm-up session for the
approaching yuletide season is
scheduled for graduate students
on Friday, December 3, from

and their (over 21) guests.
The change in location from
McCoy Hall to Shriver Hall is
In keeping with a seasonal spirit

club memberships at the party.
In time for Christmas mailing

Each Graduate Club member

Nut-Nut
We celebrate, this week, the first anniversary of the
Milton S. Eisenhower Library. And while the building
stands proud and statuesque, its patrons have been reduced to the status of pawns. The efficiency of the new
library system borders on the inhuman. Our mugshots
are taken with our books and are known as mere numbers. We are counted as we enter the building and searched when we leave.
Paintings and drawings are exhibited in the upper
hall of the library, but the immensity of the hail makes
the works virtually unnoticeable. On the lower levels
where there were once displayed lithographs the walls
are now barren with but a few busts of professors faces
turned to the wall. The long corridors on the lower
level remain unbroken, but for the color changes of the
stacks.
On some levels it appears that the walls anti windows
are in sad disrepair, and in need of cleaning.
The new efficiency dictates that no students from
other colleges should he permitted below the first level,
and not permitted in the library at all after 4:00 p.m.
This policy seems entirely unwarranted, and merely
helps to isolate Hopkins from the other college communities. There has always been a dirth of communications among the colleges in Baltimore, but this action
can only serve to aggravate a situation that is already
worse that it should be. This policy should be reversed.
While the library was never designed with humans in
mind it would be worthwhile for the library staff to consider making the library fit for humans. If the walls of
the library are to be sterile they should at least be clean,
but better the walls should he covered with paintings,
prints or lithographs. Then maybe there would he no
need to hide the lower levels of the library.

Six of One Plus Half a
Dozen of the Other
It has come to our attention that the vacations at
Hopkins are entirely too short and that it would definitely behoove the University to seriously consider an
extension of the two major academic respites that occur
during the year. If it is a policy of the university to
effect a greater geographic distribution among the undergraduates, it is a necessity that such action he taken. At
present Christmas vacation is a mear 20,160 minutes, and
even less for those students obligated to Saturday labs.
While this period at first glance seems adequate to effeclively,reconstitute the academic resources of the student,
a second look reveals that for students travelling great distances the vacation is reduced to a palsied mere halt in
their academic endeavors. A student forced to drive to
the coast for his Christmas vacation will consume approximately 6,340 hours of his time in transit—not to
count rest stop, gasoline stops, and so forth. Travel
So the exotic midweot will consume 4,123 hours.
Of course one might insist that there are other more
rapid forms of transportation—such as airplanes. This
consideration is quite sordid, however, in view of air
cost, the increase in tuition and living coots—not to
mention the general insecurity of air flight.
We therefore propose in this period of computerization of the student hotly, that a few numbers be removed from student i.d. cards and relegated to the extension of vacation periods. So be it.

defense. First, the title song—it
ls sung by the Supremes. Why,
their name alone suggests the
position Dr. Goldfoot enjoys
in the film's cosmology. Besides,
there are three Supremes-Diane, Mary and Florence—almost forcing us to consider the
Trinity. But they are Negro,
which suggests, on a purely
imagist level, blackness; and
they are women. Before the first
scene, the film has established
Itself as a portrayal of a perverted God. Secondly, Dr. Goldfoot is said repeatedly to have
raised his assistant—Igor—from
the grave. Reminiscent is it not,
of the resurrection of Lazarus by
Jesus. Thirdly, there is the existence of Dr. Goldfoot's twelve
btkini'd
girls, seemingly an
arbitrary number, until we remember that Christ had twelve
disciples.

There are also evidences of
Dr. Goldfoot's relation to Christ
Inherent in the scene structure
and spacial composition of the
film. In the final scenes, Dr.
Goldfoot is chasing the two
young men who wish to escape
his power. The motion in this sequence is entirely downward—
down steep hills in a streetcar,
downward in a car, a motorcycle.
Down. Christ is forced to descend to earth to capture the
souls of men. And the sequence
has its climax in Dr. Goldfoot's
death, his car falling off a high
cliff, an exotic red cloud freed
from the destroyed car. Crucifixion is the culmination of the
downward path. . . But then
what happens? The very next
scene is of a huge jet plane,
rising powerfully into the sky.
There is then a shot of the two
young men inside the plane,
laughing coarsely--thinking they

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, DECEMBER I, 1965

THE

have destroyed Dr. Goldfoot and
thereby freed themselves. Next
shot: Dr. Goldfoot ("Goldfoot"
—God's Fate?) appears at the
cabin door—he is pilot. They are
soaring upward with him. He is
resurrected and through him,
they approach heaven. Man's
soul is finally captured.
For all its wit and sight-gags,
this is a pessimistic film. Had its
story been told in ancient Israel,
It would have been a film of
religious epiphany; of an omnipotent being affecting deeply,
through spiritual revelation, the
lives of men. But we live in
America, in a time when man
has neglected the right to rule
his own soul, all his energy given
toward the acquisition of money
and glory. Our Christ cannot be
the son of God; we are impervious to a Christ representing
charity and humility and selfrespect.

By

MARSHALL PAUL
Sports Editor
Coach Henry Ciccarone's "new
look" may not be a Bill Russell
on the boards or a Bob Cousey
on the outside, but the Hopkins
team which takes the floor tomorrow night figures to be the
toughest, most aggressive cage
team that Homewood has seen
in years.
The backbone of this contingent is the freshman five that
opened the eyes of the school
last year. Before the roaring
crowd of 600 which turned out
for opening night's preliminary
game a season ago, they mechanically and cooly swept Loyola out of the Newton White
Athletic Center.
Ciccarone will get the maximum use out of his experienced
returnees, but the difference is
that he will have ten excellent
ballplayers to fill five positions,
instead of five to fill five.
Internal Struggle
As one coach remarked Tuesday, "Nobody plays the hot-dog
hero on this team."
Though small, the team has
depth and balance. Dave Thomas, Jim Calli, and
Willy

Schwerizfeier are all excellent
shots from the outside. Joe Carlton heads a fistfull of strong
men up front. And each of them
is going to have to fight for his
position, since there's somebody
ready to jump up and grab it.
This Internal ccmpetition will
improve a team as much as anything, and a similar situation
could be building up on the
sophomore - dominated varsity
wrestling contingent.
More Sophs
While Ciccarone's c,agers feature five seniors, one junior, and
nine sophomores, wrestling mentor Dave Blizzard has fourteen
sophs on his roster, to a total
of eleven juniors and seniors.
Looking back, the '65 frosh
quint had an 11-2 record. The
65 frosh grapplers also had only
two losses on their slate.
There was a winning drive and
a thirst for competition on these
two teams, and I don't hesitate
to add last year's frosh football
and lacrosse teams and the rest
of the '65 frosh aggregations.
With these squads as their
nuclei, both the wrestling and
basketball contingents should be
dominating their leagues by 1968.

By BARON WORMSER
Finishing off the seasOn on a
disappointing note, the varsity
crosscountry team ended in a tie
with Catholic University for
sixth place in the Mason-Dixon
Conference meet. Old Dominion
won the meet, edging American
University 86-87, as the Jays
totaled 153.
Leading the Hopkins contingent was Kevin Murphy, who
topped off a brilliant campaign
with a fourth-place finish in the
Individuals. Right behind Murphy was Jack Loomis, who finished out of the field of approximately 100 runners.
Varsity mentor Ed Polanowski
tabbed the season as "very pleasant" and noted that the hill
'n'dalers' performance proved
that Hopkins can hold its own
in both the Mason-Dixon and
Middle Atlantic Conferences,
The key problem the Jays
faced was building up a team

with depth. This dilemma was
clearly evinced this season as
each of the harriers' defeats
could be directly attributed to
an unsteady fifth position.
Looking forward to next year,
the coach stated that he was
concerned with a pending rules
change in the Mason-Dixon
Conference. Under consideration
is a motion to boost the course
length from three to four miles,
as in the Middle Atlantic Conference. This change might set
the team back since the freshmen moving up to the varsity are
accustomed to running only two
miles. However in the long run,
the coach stated that he felt the
change would prove beneficial.
Impressive in next season's
picture will be varsity returnees
Jack Loomis, Cliff Cyr, and
Forrest Chumley along with
frosh threats Jeff Laurens, Ronnie Teeter, Ralph Hingson, and
John Gardner.

By MIKE PHILLIPS
Mike Oidick's nomination to
en honorable mention berth on
the Little All-American team
and a final-game upset over
Western Maryland put a bright
finish to the '65 campaign as the
varsity football team ended up

1-6-1.
Besides this laurel the 6-2
senior-end
made
honorablemention on the Southern Division, Middle Atlantic Conference
All-Star Team — the loop names
only offensive and defensive first
teams. Oidick also finished seventh in the league in pass reeeiving.
Other
Hopkins \Conference
standouts were Phil Parthmore,
Who was sixth in the circuit in
kissing and seventh in total offense, and Bill Nickel, the division's second-best punter with a
38.1 league average.
Western Maryland Upset
Taking a look at his squad's
24-6 victory over Western Maryland in the season's finale, varsity coach Wilson Fewster was
somewhat at a loss to explain
the form reversal, and could not
really relate it to any one factor.
Ile did, however, cite improved
line play, especially by Art
Peinado, a relative lack of inJnries, and a resurgence of team

spirit as having their part in the
triumph.
**What also could have had an
effect," he continued, "was the
way we got the opening score
and took the lead for once, which
might have meant something
psychologically. After that, when
the boys held this early advantage till halftime, I think they
got the idea they could put it
away."
Scott Super-Scout
"The person who should really
get credit for the win, though, is
Bob Scott, who did a terrific
scouting job on Western Maryland. He had such detailed information on them that he must
have known more about Western
Maryland football than the

Western
Maryland
coaching
staff."

performed as follows: Henry
Schaefer, 104 attempts - 329
yards - 3.2 average; Bob Shannon, 41-141-3.4; Wally Siggers,
30-74-2.5; Jim Call. 13-54-4.1;
amid Parthmore, 59-53-0.9.
Passing Leaders
The team was third in the
Southern Division in passing
yardage, as Phil Parthmore (46
completions in 90 attempts for
529 yards), Henry Schaefer (18
of 74 for 272 yards), and Mike
Shaw (15 of 34 for 181 yards)
led the way. Oidick was the only
receiver of consequence for these
tosses, catching 31 for 436 yards.

Battle With Fords

Grapplers Feature
Sophs, Balance
By MARSHALL PAUL
Balance and an abundance of
sophomores weigh in as two key
factors this year for the varsity
wrestling team. which scrimmages Morgan here Tuesday and
the University of Baltimore four
days later.
Right now Coach Dave Blizzard, in his initial year at Hopkins, has five seniors, six juniors, and fourteen sophomores
on his roster.
In the 123 pound class are
Martin Ray, Rick Elinson, and
William Conner, while Drew
Niccolint, Pete Tripp, and Pete
Muller wrestle at 130. Joe Griggs,
Tom Copeland and Larry Leonard are at 137; and John Sopka,
Luis Costes, John Fisch, and
David Moorehead are at 145.
Battling for the top position
In the 152 pound class are Gerald Becker, John Blotzer, and
Ken Gummerson, with Doug
Lipman alone at. 160. Frank
Pergal, Bill Swartz, and Brad
Keller are at 167; Larry Corman
and Carlos Dias at 177; and
Bill Hunt and John Gayle will
be either 191 or unlimited.
Blizzard noted, "We may be
Weak in the 130 pound class and
weak in numbers, but not qualtty, at 160. However, we have
several boys at 152 who could
move up."
After watching his charges
scrimmage Towson, the coach
noted that Elinson, Griggs, Costes, Gtunmerson, performed well.
He noted that in the 167 pound
plans Keller will give Swartz the
type of competition that will
enable both to develop to the
fullest.
Blizzard also noted that Hunt
and Corman look to be in line
iior number one berths. Corman
is the squad's only returning
senior with a letter.
The grapplers open their season on December 15 against
Lebanon Valley. Captains will be
announced today.
On the frosh roster are Ken
Sherman and Rich Dryden at
03; Greg Evans, 130; Barry
ICnotts, Sam Pepkowitz, and
Giarson Roodman at 137. At 145
axe Harry Gotwals and Charles
Steinberg. John Grahm wrestles
152 and Tim Wex 160. Dennis
Estis and John Peck are 167,
aeorge Schrodel and John
p.abbs will wrestle 177 or 191;
and Joe Saul is in the unlimited
bracket.

tomorrow at 1:00 P.M. Coed
swimming will follow each
day's competition. Bring a
date.

Klarner Working
On Fresh Fish
By JIM SLOAN
The as yet unpolished varsity
swimming team flails away at
Swarthmore on December 16 but
will have over a month to get
ready for its first meet in front
of Hopkins fans.
With his first home match
slated for January 7 against
Lycoming College, Coach Bill
Klarner noted that this will be
another development year for
his second-season squad.
We're not yet representative of
a good college team," stated
Kleiner, "but the team shows
good spirit and has made progress."
Prediction
Klarner predicted that it
would take several years for a
solid lineup to evolve. The squad
Is composed of many swimmers
who lack high-school swimming
experience, so emphasis will be
placed on learning this season.
The varsity team consists of
Gary Brittenham, Rudy Busby,
Robert Butler, Robert Costa,
Alan Friedman, Al Henry, Terry
Hird, George Kempf, Paul Kesmodel, Eugene Linfors, Timothy
Lyons, Richard Miles, Gerald
Molnar, Richard Moore, Peter
Terzian,
Richard
Tomasulo,
Douglas Tribull, and Curt Zimansky. Managers are George
Alapas and Robert Kaiser.

Europe for $1100
Switzerland — A do-it-yourself summer in Europe is now available.
The new plan makes a trip to Europe,
including transportation, possible for
less than $100. A complete do-ityourself prospectus including instructions, money saving tips and a large
selection of job opportunities along
with discount fours and application
forms may be obtained by writing
to Dept. X, International Travel Est.,
68 Herrengasse, Vaduz, Liechtenstein
(Switzerland) enclosing $1 with your
inquiry to cover the cost of the
material, overseas handling and air
mail postage.

the freshman squad.

Concerned members of the
Hopkins community met with
the Hopkins Committee for Basic
Freedoms Tuesday, November 30
in Levering Hall. All those who
attended the public meeting were
incorporated into the committee.
The group discussed its relation with the administration.
it was suggested that the committee should develop detailed
proposals and present them to
the administration. Another suggestion was that the committee
should point out the inadequacies
of present administration policy
and use publicity to prod the
administration into action.
After some debate, it was generally decided that the administration has the experience and
the responsibility to work out
the necessary programs. The
committee's object will be to
work out feasible general programs, present details where
possible, and to publicize those
areas where the administration
does not act.
Subconunittees Formed
Eventually, the group decided
to split into three subcommittees on admissions, housing, and
employment. Each committee
Will investigate specific actions
bi its area and report back to
the group or the administration.
Until the next meeting, sched(tied for December 7 at 7:30
P.M., each committee could act
on its own if an opportunity
arose to aid desegregation of
the campus.

times, although only 15 people

list of quality Negro schools.

students could be found to

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, DECEMBER 3, 1965

State's Attorney To Speak
Charles E. Moylan, Jr., State's
Attorney of Baltimore City, will
speak at a joint meeting
of the Hopkins Young Democrats
and Debate Council on Wednesday, December 8, at 4:00 P.M.
in the Reading Room of Levering Hall. The subject of Moylan's
talk will be "Crime in Baltimore."
This year's debate topic is
"Resolved: That law enforcement agencies in the United
States should be given greater
freedom in the investigation and
prosecution of crime." The topic
is chiefly concerned with recent
Supreme Court decisions which
place limitations on police and
states' attornies in their attempts to catch and convict
criminals. Moyan will discuss his
views on the Su,perne Court decisions during his speech.

The Young Democrats are cohosting the affair because Mr.
Moylan is widely regarded as a
political comer in the State of
Maryland. The State's Attorney
has already been asked to run
for Attorney-General of the
State on one ticket and smart
politicians are predicting that
he will be the next AttorneyGeneral and then Governor.
The debaters and the Young
Democrats expect a full house
for Mr. Moylan's visit. He will
be speaking the day after William F. Buckley's appearance
and "the more liberal members
of the Hopkins community regard Moylan's speech as a breath
of fresh air following the erstwhile New York mayoralty candidate," according to Jon Alpert,
who is president of both organizations.

Class Day Over
Class day went off well,
Booster Club President Griffith
reported, but no one seems to
know who won. Student participation was limited when a few
faculty members scheduled labs
for that Friday afternoon, a
practice which an administration
spokesman decried inasmuch as
the afternoon of the Friday before Thanksgiving is an official
University holiday.
The first and last Hopkins AllSchool blast was held two weeks
ago in what now remains of the
likYrC building. Several windows
were broken and doors were
ripped off their hinges. The
Major problem, however, was the
chaotic mess which the maintenance crew faced the following
day. Griffith admitted that "he
didn't realize that students—
especially freshmen—would go
ape as they did." He also noted
that many males attending the
affair were non-Hopkins men.

Returning to speak at Hopkins
will be a homecoming for Moylan who received his B.A. here
in 1952. Among other activities,
while he was at Hopkins he
served as president of the Council. Moylan went on to the University of Maryland Law School
where he was President of the
Student Bar Association and National Vice-President of the
American Law Students Association. Shortly thereafter he
entered the army and graduated
first in his class at the Army
Intelligence Center at Fort Holebird. After serving as a Counter
Intelligence agent in West Germany, Moylan returned to Baltimore and entered Maryland
politics. He has been State's Attorney for Baltimore City for
over a year and has also served
as President of the Maryland
Young Democratic Clubs, He is
now serving on the Board of
Directors of many public service
organizations including the National Conference of Christians
and Jews.

Nut-Nut
We celebrate, this week, the first anniversary of the
Milton S. Eisenhower Library. And while the building
stands proud and statuesque, its patrons have been reduced to the status of pawns. The efficiency of the new
library system borders on the inhuman. Our mugshots
are taken with our books and are known as mere numbers. We are counted as we enter the building and searched when we leave.
Paintings and drawings are exhibited in the upper
hall of the library, but the immensity of the hail makes
the works virtually unnoticeable. On the lower levels
where there were once displayed lithographs the walls
are now barren with but a few busts of professors faces
turned to the wall. The long corridors on the lower
level remain unbroken, but for the color changes of the
stacks.
On some levels it appears that the walls anti windows
are in sad disrepair, and in need of cleaning.
The new efficiency dictates that no students from
other colleges should he permitted below the first level,
and not permitted in the library at all after 4:00 p.m.
This policy seems entirely unwarranted, and merely
helps to isolate Hopkins from the other college communities. There has always been a dirth of communications among the colleges in Baltimore, but this action
can only serve to aggravate a situation that is already
worse that it should be. This policy should be reversed.
While the library was never designed with humans in
mind it would be worthwhile for the library staff to consider making the library fit for humans. If the walls of
the library are to be sterile they should at least be clean,
but better the walls should he covered with paintings,
prints or lithographs. Then maybe there would he no
need to hide the lower levels of the library.

Six of One Plus Half a
Dozen of the Other
It has come to our attention that the vacations at
Hopkins are entirely too short and that it would definitely behoove the University to seriously consider an
extension of the two major academic respites that occur
during the year. If it is a policy of the university to
effect a greater geographic distribution among the undergraduates, it is a necessity that such action he taken. At
present Christmas vacation is a mear 20,160 minutes, and
even less for those students obligated to Saturday labs.
While this period at first glance seems adequate to effeclively,reconstitute the academic resources of the student,
a second look reveals that for students travelling great distances the vacation is reduced to a palsied mere halt in
their academic endeavors. A student forced to drive to
the coast for his Christmas vacation will consume approximately 6,340 hours of his time in transit—not to
count rest stop, gasoline stops, and so forth. Travel
So the exotic midweot will consume 4,123 hours.
Of course one might insist that there are other more
rapid forms of transportation—such as airplanes. This
consideration is quite sordid, however, in view of air
cost, the increase in tuition and living coots—not to
mention the general insecurity of air flight.
We therefore propose in this period of computerization of the student hotly, that a few numbers be removed from student i.d. cards and relegated to the extension of vacation periods. So be it.

defense. First, the title song—it
ls sung by the Supremes. Why,
their name alone suggests the
position Dr. Goldfoot enjoys
in the film's cosmology. Besides,
there are three Supremes-Diane, Mary and Florence—almost forcing us to consider the
Trinity. But they are Negro,
which suggests, on a purely
imagist level, blackness; and
they are women. Before the first
scene, the film has established
Itself as a portrayal of a perverted God. Secondly, Dr. Goldfoot is said repeatedly to have
raised his assistant—Igor—from
the grave. Reminiscent is it not,
of the resurrection of Lazarus by
Jesus. Thirdly, there is the existence of Dr. Goldfoot's twelve
btkini'd
girls, seemingly an
arbitrary number, until we remember that Christ had twelve
disciples.

There are also evidences of
Dr. Goldfoot's relation to Christ
Inherent in the scene structure
and spacial composition of the
film. In the final scenes, Dr.
Goldfoot is chasing the two
young men who wish to escape
his power. The motion in this sequence is entirely downward—
down steep hills in a streetcar,
downward in a car, a motorcycle.
Down. Christ is forced to descend to earth to capture the
souls of men. And the sequence
has its climax in Dr. Goldfoot's
death, his car falling off a high
cliff, an exotic red cloud freed
from the destroyed car. Crucifixion is the culmination of the
downward path. . . But then
what happens? The very next
scene is of a huge jet plane,
rising powerfully into the sky.
There is then a shot of the two
young men inside the plane,
laughing coarsely--thinking they

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, DECEMBER I, 1965

THE

have destroyed Dr. Goldfoot and
thereby freed themselves. Next
shot: Dr. Goldfoot ("Goldfoot"
—God's Fate?) appears at the
cabin door—he is pilot. They are
soaring upward with him. He is
resurrected and through him,
they approach heaven. Man's
soul is finally captured.
For all its wit and sight-gags,
this is a pessimistic film. Had its
story been told in ancient Israel,
It would have been a film of
religious epiphany; of an omnipotent being affecting deeply,
through spiritual revelation, the
lives of men. But we live in
America, in a time when man
has neglected the right to rule
his own soul, all his energy given
toward the acquisition of money
and glory. Our Christ cannot be
the son of God; we are impervious to a Christ representing
charity and humility and selfrespect.

By

MARSHALL PAUL
Sports Editor
Coach Henry Ciccarone's "new
look" may not be a Bill Russell
on the boards or a Bob Cousey
on the outside, but the Hopkins
team which takes the floor tomorrow night figures to be the
toughest, most aggressive cage
team that Homewood has seen
in years.
The backbone of this contingent is the freshman five that
opened the eyes of the school
last year. Before the roaring
crowd of 600 which turned out
for opening night's preliminary
game a season ago, they mechanically and cooly swept Loyola out of the Newton White
Athletic Center.
Ciccarone will get the maximum use out of his experienced
returnees, but the difference is
that he will have ten excellent
ballplayers to fill five positions,
instead of five to fill five.
Internal Struggle
As one coach remarked Tuesday, "Nobody plays the hot-dog
hero on this team."
Though small, the team has
depth and balance. Dave Thomas, Jim Calli, and
Willy

Schwerizfeier are all excellent
shots from the outside. Joe Carlton heads a fistfull of strong
men up front. And each of them
is going to have to fight for his
position, since there's somebody
ready to jump up and grab it.
This Internal ccmpetition will
improve a team as much as anything, and a similar situation
could be building up on the
sophomore - dominated varsity
wrestling contingent.
More Sophs
While Ciccarone's c,agers feature five seniors, one junior, and
nine sophomores, wrestling mentor Dave Blizzard has fourteen
sophs on his roster, to a total
of eleven juniors and seniors.
Looking back, the '65 frosh
quint had an 11-2 record. The
65 frosh grapplers also had only
two losses on their slate.
There was a winning drive and
a thirst for competition on these
two teams, and I don't hesitate
to add last year's frosh football
and lacrosse teams and the rest
of the '65 frosh aggregations.
With these squads as their
nuclei, both the wrestling and
basketball contingents should be
dominating their leagues by 1968.

By BARON WORMSER
Finishing off the seasOn on a
disappointing note, the varsity
crosscountry team ended in a tie
with Catholic University for
sixth place in the Mason-Dixon
Conference meet. Old Dominion
won the meet, edging American
University 86-87, as the Jays
totaled 153.
Leading the Hopkins contingent was Kevin Murphy, who
topped off a brilliant campaign
with a fourth-place finish in the
Individuals. Right behind Murphy was Jack Loomis, who finished out of the field of approximately 100 runners.
Varsity mentor Ed Polanowski
tabbed the season as "very pleasant" and noted that the hill
'n'dalers' performance proved
that Hopkins can hold its own
in both the Mason-Dixon and
Middle Atlantic Conferences,
The key problem the Jays
faced was building up a team

with depth. This dilemma was
clearly evinced this season as
each of the harriers' defeats
could be directly attributed to
an unsteady fifth position.
Looking forward to next year,
the coach stated that he was
concerned with a pending rules
change in the Mason-Dixon
Conference. Under consideration
is a motion to boost the course
length from three to four miles,
as in the Middle Atlantic Conference. This change might set
the team back since the freshmen moving up to the varsity are
accustomed to running only two
miles. However in the long run,
the coach stated that he felt the
change would prove beneficial.
Impressive in next season's
picture will be varsity returnees
Jack Loomis, Cliff Cyr, and
Forrest Chumley along with
frosh threats Jeff Laurens, Ronnie Teeter, Ralph Hingson, and
John Gardner.

W.M. Upset; End Honored
By MIKE PHILLIPS
Mike Oidick's nomination to
en honorable mention berth on
the Little All-American team
and a final-game upset over
Western Maryland put a bright
finish to the '65 campaign as the
varsity football team ended up

1-6-1.
Besides this laurel the 6-2
senior-end
made
honorablemention on the Southern Division, Middle Atlantic Conference
All-Star Team — the loop names
only offensive and defensive first
teams. Oidick also finished seventh in the league in pass reeeiving.
Other
Hopkins \Conference
standouts were Phil Parthmore,
Who was sixth in the circuit in
kissing and seventh in total offense, and Bill Nickel, the division's second-best punter with a
38.1 league average.
Western Maryland Upset
Taking a look at his squad's
24-6 victory over Western Maryland in the season's finale, varsity coach Wilson Fewster was
somewhat at a loss to explain
the form reversal, and could not
really relate it to any one factor.
Ile did, however, cite improved
line play, especially by Art
Peinado, a relative lack of inJnries, and a resurgence of team

spirit as having their part in the
triumph.
**What also could have had an
effect," he continued, "was the
way we got the opening score
and took the lead for once, which
might have meant something
psychologically. After that, when
the boys held this early advantage till halftime, I think they
got the idea they could put it
away."
Scott Super-Scout
"The person who should really
get credit for the win, though, is
Bob Scott, who did a terrific
scouting job on Western Maryland. He had such detailed information on them that he must
have known more about Western
Maryland football than the

Western
Maryland
coaching
staff."
The squad's leading rushers
performed as follows: Henry
Schaefer, 104 attempts - 329
yards - 3.2 average; Bob Shannon, 41-141-3.4; Wally Siggers,
30-74-2.5; Jim Call. 13-54-4.1;
amid Parthmore, 59-53-0.9.
Passing Leaders
The team was third in the
Southern Division in passing
yardage, as Phil Parthmore (46
completions in 90 attempts for
529 yards), Henry Schaefer (18
of 74 for 272 yards), and Mike
Shaw (15 of 34 for 181 yards)
led the way. Oidick was the only
receiver of consequence for these
tosses, catching 31 for 436 yards.

Balance and an abundance of
sophomores weigh in as two key

wrestling team. which scrimmages Morgan here Tuesday and
the University of Baltimore four
days later.
Right now Coach Dave Blizzard, in his initial year at Hopkins, has five seniors, six juniors, and fourteen sophomores
on his roster.
In the 123 pound class are
Martin Ray, Rick Elinson, and
William Conner, while Drew
Niccolint, Pete Tripp, and Pete
Muller wrestle at 130. Joe Griggs,
Tom Copeland and Larry Leonard are at 137; and John Sopka,
Luis Costes, John Fisch, and
David Moorehead are at 145.
Battling for the top position

Ken Gummerson, with Doug
Lipman alone at. 160. Frank
Pergal, Bill Swartz, and Brad
Keller are at 167; Larry Corman
and Carlos Dias at 177; and
Bill Hunt and John Gayle will
be either 191 or unlimited.

Weak in the 130 pound class and
weak in numbers, but not qualtty, at 160. However, we have
several boys at 152 who could
move up."

scrimmage Towson, the coach
noted that Elinson, Griggs, Costes, Gtunmerson, performed well.

plans Keller will give Swartz the
type of competition that will
enable both to develop to the
fullest.
Blizzard also noted that Hunt
and Corman look to be in line
iior number one berths. Corman
is the squad's only returning
senior with a letter.

announced today.

axe Harry Gotwals and Charles

aeorge Schrodel and John
p.abbs will wrestle 177 or 191;

bracket.

The as yet unpolished varsity
swimming team flails away at

slated for January 7 against
Lycoming College, Coach Bill
Klarner noted that this will be
another development year for
his second-season squad.
We're not yet representative of
a good college team," stated
Kleiner, "but the team shows
good spirit and has made progress."
Prediction
Klarner predicted that it
would take several years for a
solid lineup to evolve. The squad
Is composed of many swimmers
who lack high-school swimming
experience, so emphasis will be
placed on learning this season.

Molnar, Richard Moore, Peter
Terzian,
Richard
Tomasulo,
Douglas Tribull, and Curt Zimansky. Managers are George
Alapas and Robert Kaiser.
